Scholar Foundation Kai Dai (Huaibei Normal University) was invited as a member of the Youth Editorial Board of Chinese Journal of Catalysis, Renewable and Sustainable Energy, Chinese Journal of Structural Chemistry and Acta Physico-Chimica Sinica. Prof. Kai Dai received his B.A. degree from Anhui University (China) in 2002, and Ph.D. degree from Shanghai University (China) in 2007. He worked in Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2007, and then in Huaibei Normal University in 2010. He is Distinguished Young Scholars Recipients of Natural Science Foundation of Anhui Province (2018) and serves as the head of Anhui Provincial Excellent research and innovation team in universities (2022) and Anhui Provincial Teaching Team (2019). He has also been invited by Xi'an Jiaotong Liverpool University to be a visiting Professor and PhD co-supervisor since 2022. His research interests mainly focus on semiconductor nanomaterials for solar energy conversion. He has published more than 150 peer-reviewed papers, including 11 hot paper of ESI and 24 highly cited papers of ESI. This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (22278169, 22179026, U20A20237, 52371218), the Excellent scientific research and innovation team of Education Department of Anhui Province (2022AH010028), the Major projects of Education Department of Anhui Province (2022AH040068), the Anhui Provincial Quality Engineering Project (2022sx134), the Innovation Platform and The unique photocatalytic mechanism of S-scheme heterojunction can be used to study new and efficient photocatalysts. By carefully selecting semiconductors for S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts, it is possible to reduce the rate of photogenerated carrier recombination and increase the conversion efficiency of light into energy. Chalcogenides are a group of compounds that include sulfides and selenides (e.g., CdS, ZnS, Bi2S3, MoS2, ZnSe, CdSe, and CuSe). Chalcogenides have attracted considerable attention as heterojunction photocatalysts owing to their narrow bandgap, wide light absorption range, and excellent photoreduction properties. This paper presents a thorough analysis of S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts based on chalcogenides. Following an introduction to the fundamental characteristics and benefits of S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts, various chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst synthesis techniques are summarized. These photocatalysts are used in numerous significant photocatalytic reactions, including the reduction of carbon dioxide, synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, conversion of organic matter, generation of hydrogen from water, nitrogen fixation, degradation of organic pollutants, and sterilization. In addition, cutting-edge characterization techniques, including in situ characterization techniques, are discussed to validate the steady and transient states of photocatalysts with an S-scheme heterojunction. Finally, the design and challenges of chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts are explored and recommended in light of state-of-the-art research. Graphical Abstract This paper presents a thorough analysis of S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts based on chalcogenides. Keywords Photocatalysis Chalcogenide S-scheme heterojunction Charge separation Application 1 Introduction People now experience the convenience of contemporary science and technology, together with the pollution and energy storage issues that come with living in an industrial society, thanks to the rapid advancement of modern science, technology, and industry. The overdevelopment and consumption of non-renewable traditional fossil energy sources, such as coal and petroleum, have caused increasingly serious environmental problems and energy crises; therefore, we urgently need to develop green, renewable, and clean energy to solve the problems created by an over-reliance on traditional fossil energy. Solar energy is a renewable, clean, and green energy source that has gained considerable attention in recent decades, and solar water heaters, solar greenhouses, and solar batteries are being used increasingly. In 1972, Fujishima et al. [1] first proposed that the photoelectrochemical reaction of a TiO2 anode material in water (H2O) can produce H2 and oxygen (O2), realizing the conversion of solar energy to chemical energy and opening up a major avenue for semiconductor photocatalysis. Semiconductor-based photocatalytic technology can effectively convert solar energy into chemical energy that can be stored. It is green and clean and alleviates the energy shortage problem. After decades of research, breakthroughs have been made in CO2 reduction [2–4], photolysis of H2O to produce H2 [5,6], and degradation of pollutants [7], which also have broad application prospects in environmental protection [8]. Photocatalysis has become a promising method for the development and utilization of solar power, and the selection of appropriate photocatalysts is key to achieving good photocatalytic activity. Therefore, photocatalyst materials must have a wide range of light absorption capacities, sufficient photocatalytic reaction active sites, fast and effective separation of charge carriers, high redox activity, and good reaction stability [9–13]. For semiconductor photocatalysts, the bandgap size and energy band structure determine the photoabsorption characteristics and redox capacity of the photogenerated charge carriers. Chalcogenides, including sulfides and selenides, have drawn considerable interest because of their superior photoreduction capabilities, extensive light-absorption capacity, and abundant active sites (Fig. 1 ) [14,15]. Compared to TiO2, which is a typical metal oxide used for photocatalytic applications, metal sulfides usually have a smaller band gap, which endows them with great potential for photocatalytic reactions driven by visible and infrared light. In addition, transition-metal selenides have received extensive attention because of their narrow band gap, excellent conductivity, and good H+ adsorption [16]. In recent years, many chalcogenide-based photocatalysts, including CdS [17], ZnS [18], Bi2S3 [19], MoS2 [20], In4SnS8 [21,22], ZnIn2S4 [23], Mn x Cd1‒x S [24], ZnSe [25], CdSe [26], and CuSe [27], have been developed. However, single chalcogenide-based photocatalysts have the disadvantages of limited light absorption intensity and serious merging of electrons and holes. In addition, when selecting a single-component photocatalyst, a small-bandgap photocatalyst should be selected for a wide light absorption range; however, this conflicts with the large bandgap required for good redox ability. Heterojunction photocatalysts formed by combining two different semiconductors can effectively improve the photocatalytic activity and light absorption range. After studying many characteristics of traditional heterojunction photocatalysts, Yu et al. [28] developed a step-scheme (S-scheme) semiconductor heterojunction with broad application prospects owing to its high light utilization and strong redox capacity. Therefore, combining chalcogenides with other materials and constructing S-scheme heterojunctions are promising and effective ways to overcome these difficulties. Research on chalcogenides in the field of photocatalysis has attracted considerable attention, and chalcogenide-based heterojunctions have been reviewed from different perspectives. Adabala et al. [29] examined advancements in the photoreduction of CO2 using metal chalcogenide-based photocatalysts, including sulfides, selenides, and tellurides, and described the reaction mechanism and modification in detail. Hussain et al. [30] discussed the synthesis and application of green-synthetic Se nanoparticles in detail. Additionally, Li et al. [31] reviewed photocatalysts based on MoS2, encompassing their applications and alterations. Examining different chalcogenide-based heterojunctions is essential for a comprehensive understanding of recent research trends. As shown in Fig. 2 , in this review article, we discuss the principles and basic properties of S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts and introduce the methods of synthesis and related characteristics of chalcogenide-based heterojunction photocatalysts in detail. Furthermore, a summary of the use of chalcogenide-based heterojunction photocatalysts for energy, environmental safeguarding, and pharmaceutical safety is provided. Different characterization techniques have also been described and reviewed, including some in situ characterization methods that are utilized to confirm the electron transfer mechanism and generate products. These methods are useful in the study of the heterojunction photocatalytic mechanism. Finally, we discuss the challenges that must be addressed to enhance the photocatalytic efficiency of chalcogenide-based heterojunction photocatalysts. 2 Basic characteristics of S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts 2.1 The reaction principle of photocatalysis Photocatalytic reactions are similar in many ways to photosynthesis in that they can absorb solar energy and convert it into chemical energy. However, in natural photosynthesis, light energy is used as the driving force to drive chemical reactions, whereas photocatalytic reactions require a semiconductor photocatalyst as the medium, and photons are regarded as reactants in the reaction. Upon exposure to sunlight, the semiconductor catalyst absorbs photon energy exceeding the band gap of the semiconductor photocatalyst. The semiconductor is effectively excited, and a photogenerated electron-hole pair is generated. Electrons move toward the lower end of the conduction band (CB) and leave holes at the upper end of the valence band (VB). Some electrons and holes recombine inside the semiconductor and are dissipated as thermal energy. When the electrons and holes in other parts are transferred to the semiconductor surface, they undergo redox reactions with different substances on the semiconductor surface. The reduced electrons participate in the photocatalytic decomposition of hydrogen ions in H2O to produce H2 and react with nitrogen adsorbed on the semiconductor surface to produce ammonia gas (NH3) to complete nitrogen fixation. They can also reduce CO2 to CH4, CH3OH, HCOOH, HCHO, and other hydrocarbon organic compounds and can be recycled [32]. In addition, they can react with the O2 adsorbed on the surface to produce a superoxide anion (•O2 ‒) to degrade organic pollutants. Oxidative vacancies can directly participate in oxidation reactions and degrade pollutants to H2O and CO2; they are also capable of interacting with H2O2 to generate hydroxyl radicals (•OH), aiding in the breakdown of organic contaminants. Superoxide anions, holes, and hydroxyl radicals work together to decompose organic pollutants and generate H2O and CO2, effectively reducing environmental pollution. 2.2 Development of S-scheme heterojunction Heterojunction photocatalytic materials are formed by coupling two semiconductor photocatalysts with an energy band-interlaced structure, which has the advantages of a wide absorption spectrum, high carrier concentration, and low recombination rate. In the early research stages, heterojunction photocatalysts were mainly classified into two types: traditional type-II heterojunction photocatalysts and photocatalysts with Z-scheme heterojunctions [28]. As depicted in Fig. 3(a) , in the traditional type-II heterojunction photocatalyst, the two coupled semiconductors (semiconductors 1 and 2 are defined as S1 and S2, respectively) are excited by light to produce pairs of electrons and holes, where the electrons migrate from the top of the respective VB to the bottom of the respective CB, and the holes are generated in the VB. The electrons produced by photogeneration move from the CB of S1 to the CB of S2. The hole created by the light shifts from the VB of S2 to the VB of S1, moving in the reverse direction. After the photogenerated electrons and holes accumulate in the CB of S2 and the VB of S1, they engage in photocatalytic reduction and oxidation reactions, respectively. The potential difference between the semiconductor components is used to determine the spatial distribution of the photogenerated charges. However, in terms of dynamics, the repulsion between electrons on the two-semiconductor CB is not conducive to the transfer of photogenerated electrons, and the transfer of photogenerated holes is prevented [33]. From a thermodynamic perspective, this mode of photogenerated charge migration reduces redox capacity and hinders the photocatalytic reaction, which is a mechanistic problem for traditional type-II heterojunction photocatalysts. To enhance the redox ability of photocatalysts, Bard [34] introduced the concept of a conventional Z-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst in 1979, which is similar to the photosynthetic photoreaction process in nature. Its electron transfer path resembles the English letter Z, hence the name Z-scheme photocatalytic system. Z-scheme heterojunctions can be divided into liquid Z-scheme heterojunctions with free redox ion pairs as the connecting medium (Fig. 3(b)), all-solid Z-scheme heterojunctions with electronic conductors as the medium (Fig. 3(c)), and direct Z-scheme heterojunctions without a medium and in direct contact (Fig. 3(d)) [35,36]. However, the members of the Z-scheme heterojunction family face unresolved problems. After the introduction of the redox ion pair, it is affected by the reversibility of the redox medium and the shading effect, which limits its application scope. The solid medium of the entirely solid Z-scheme heterojunction accelerates charge transfer, but it does not fundamentally solve the charge-transfer problem that exists in conventional Z-scheme heterojunctions. The concept of a direct Z-scheme heterojunction can be traced back to 2001 [37], but its mechanism and reaction efficiency still require improvement. Both type-II and Z-scheme heterojunctions mentioned above exhibit various errors and controversies in charge transfer and the introduction of new media, which seriously hinder the development of heterojunction photocatalysts. S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts have been proposed to overcome these challenges. An S-scheme heterojunction comprises a combination of oxidation (OP) and reduction (RP) photocatalysts. RPs have higher CB and VB positions and Fermi levels than OPs. Figs. 4(a–c) illustrate the mechanism underlying the photocatalytic reaction of the S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst. When the two semiconductors are in contact, the electrons of the RP spontaneously transfer to the OP because of the difference in their Fermi levels, until the Fermi levels of the two semiconductors reach equilibrium. At this time, at the RP interface, a layer characterized by electron depletion emerges, featuring an ascending band of positive energy, and an electron accumulation layer with a downward and negative energy band is formed at the OP interface. Concurrently, an inherent electric field emerges at the interface, extending from the RP to the OP [38,39]. Post-illumination, the inherent electric field causes the photogenerated electrons at the CB of the OP to shift to the VB of the RP, and under the action of Coulombic force and energy band bending, the electrons are effectively prevented from migrating from the CB of the RP to the CB of the OP. The transferred electrons are further excited and transferred to the CB of the RP, resulting in a stronger reduction ability. Finally, because of the inherent electric field and bending of the band at the boundary, the photogenerated charges with poor redox ability recombine at the interface, and the photogenerated electrons in the CB of the RP with strong redox ability and the photogenerated holes in the VB of the OP with strong redox ability are retained, thereby improving the redox ability of the catalytic system. 2.3 The role of S-scheme heterojunction In semiconductor photocatalysts, under the action of light energy, the semiconductor's electrons are stimulated and transferred to the surface, where photocatalytic redox reactions occur. In the photocatalytic reaction, a single catalyst with a narrow band gap has good light absorption ability, but single-component photocatalysts have weak redox ability and poor photocatalytic activity. Fortunately, research on heterojunction photocatalysts has made significant contributions to the improvement of photocatalytic performance. In contrast to type II and Z-scheme heterojunctions, S-scheme heterojunctions offer broader charge-transfer routes and a more precise choice of semiconductors. The main properties of the S-scheme photocatalytic heterojunctions are summarized below. (1) Enhanced use of light: Absorption of light is the first step in photocatalytic reactions. The construction of S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts involves the use of various materials with distinct electronic configurations and light absorption capabilities, leading to the absorption of a broader spectrum of light and improved light absorption capacities. At the same time, due to the unique charge transfer mechanism of the S-scheme heterojunction, the photoelectrons and holes involved in the reaction are effectively retained. (2) Enhanced utilization of electrons and holes produced by light: In semiconductor photocatalysts, the photogenerated electrons and holes are divided to create electron-hole pairs. In a single photocatalyst, the recombination of electrons and holes significantly impacts the photocatalytic reaction; however, in multicomponent heterojunction photocatalysts, the difference in Fermi levels causes a transfer of electrons, which reduces the composite consumption of electrons and holes compared to that in single-component photocatalysts to a certain extent. In addition, unlike in type-I heterojunctions, photoelectrons and holes accumulate in the CB of the OP and VB of the RP, respectively. In the S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst, the useless electrons and holes are reconstituted and eliminated at the interface, whereas the strong photoelectrons in the CB of the RP and the holes in the VB of the OP are retained for the photocatalytic reaction. (3) Improving the photocatalytic stability of photocatalysts: The photocorrosion of chalcogenide photocatalysts, especially sulfide photocatalysts, under light irradiation is a problem. During the photocorrosion of the sulfide photocatalyst, photogenerated holes with oxidizing properties can readily interact with sulfide S2‒ ions to create S0 (without O2), SO3 2‒, or SO4 2‒ (with O2). Such autoxidation not only causes the loss of sulfide but also leads to photocatalyst inactivation as the reaction proceeds. Fortunately, combining chalcogenides with other semiconductors to form S-scheme heterojunctions can divert the photogenerated holes from the chalcogenide photocatalyst and prevent autoxidation, thereby improving the stability of the photocatalyst. In summary, the photocatalytic process of the S-scheme heterojunction contributes significantly to the development of innovative photocatalysts, enhancing the efficiency of the use of light energy and boosting charge recombination. In addition, there are technical problems related to surface reactions in photocatalytic systems, which usually manifest as insufficient light absorption capacity and a low reaction rate at the interface. For chalcogenide photocatalysts, surface modifications such as hydrogenation engineering can enhance the photoabsorption ability by generating surface disorder on the photocatalyst surface, and the surface organic modification of the photocatalyst can increase the absorption ability of the reactants to improve the reaction rate at the photocatalyst interface. Through the reasonable construction of chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts and adopting the corresponding modification work, the photocatalytic reduction in CO2, hydrogen production, and organic matter degradation in the areas of application can be further realized. 3 Preparation method An S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst is composed of reducing semiconductors with a small work function and high Fermi level connected to oxidizing semiconductors with a large work function and low Fermi level; therefore, the semiconductors should be screened before combination. Moreover, the close contact between two distinct semiconductors, leading to the creation of a heterojunction, alters their physicochemical characteristics. To obtain the expected chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst, several factors should be considered during the preparation process: adjusting the energy band structure to enhance the light absorption capacity, improving the migration of photogenerated charge carriers to the surface for reaction, adjusting the photocatalyst morphological structure to increase the number of active sites, and increasing the stability of the photocatalyst. Therefore, the choice of the preparation method determines the dimensions, configuration, and surface conditions of the photocatalyst, which in turn affect its performance. Chalcogenide-based heterojunction photocatalysts should be prepared using green, environmentally friendly, and inexpensive synthetic methods. Currently, there are multiple techniques for creating S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts, each with distinct features, benefits, and drawbacks. The following section outlines the various techniques for creating such photocatalysts, including hydrothermal methods, chemical bath deposition, precipitation, electrospinning, and in situ photochemical deposition. 3.1 Hydrothermal and solvothermal synthesis Hydrothermal and solvothermal synthesis refer to the use of aqueous and organic solvents, respectively, as reaction systems in a special closed container, creating a high-temperature and high-pressure environment such that the material is dissolved, recrystallized, and synthesized. Using hydrothermal and solvothermal synthesis, nanoparticles with high purity, small grain diameters, and well-developed grains can be obtained by adjusting the reaction parameters [40,41]. Yang et al. [42] used stepwise hydrothermal synthesis to synthesize an In2S3/Zn3In2S6 composite consisting of two reducing photocatalysts for the simultaneous degradation of bisphenol A and photocatalytic H2 generation, maintaining the hierarchical morphological characteristics of Zn3In2S6 and promoting the formation of an S-scheme heterojunction between In2S3 and Zn3In2S6 through this manufacturing process. Solvothermal synthesis is commonly used to prepare materials that do not form in aqueous solutions or are sensitive to water. Therefore, solvothermal synthesis compensates for the deficiencies of the hydrothermal method. As shown in Fig. 5(a) , Bai et al. [43] applied a two-step solvothermal technique to fabricate an internal electric field-modulated ZnIn2S4-NiSe2 S-scheme heterojunction on TiO3C2 MXene. In this photocatalyst, ZnIn2S4 (ZIS) nanosheets were grown extensionally and uniformly on both surfaces of MXene (MX) under solvothermal reaction conditions, and MX-ZIS with a large specific surface area was constructed. At the interface of the heterojunction depicted in Fig. 5(b), the Schottky barrier at the MX-ZIS interface provided a fast channel for the charge shift from ZIS to MX, constituting a coupled internal electrical field inside ZIS-NiSe2 and accelerating the formation of the S-scheme heterojunction. Furthermore, the structural forms of materials prepared by solvothermal synthesis differ from those of materials prepared by hydrothermal synthesis. Yu et al. [44] grew two-dimensional Bi2MoO6 semiconductor nanosheets rich in surface oxygen vacancies on one-dimensional In2S3 nanotubes via solvothermal synthesis. This hollow tubular structure modified with 2D nanosheets increased the number of interfacial contacts, thus providing more reaction sites and improving the utilization rate of the photogenerated charge carriers. In addition, well-defined heterojunctions can effectively improve the efficiency of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. For example, an appropriate combination of one-dimensional and two-dimensional semiconductors. Generally, hydrothermal and solvothermal methods for the synthesis of chalcogenide photocatalysts are relatively easy to perform, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly. High-purity photocatalysts with different morphologies can be prepared by adjusting the reaction parameters such as solvent, temperature, pH, and precursor [45,46]. The principle of the lytic heat method is similar to that of the hydrothermal method, but with an expanded application of the hydrothermal method. Therefore, the characteristics of the target products should be considered when selecting a specific synthetic method. 3.2 Chemical bath deposition (CBD) CBD is a liquid-phase epitaxial technology that can effectively deposit bath solutions on substrate surfaces. The low deposition temperature allows the use of different substrates and solutions in the reaction. Compared to other synthesis methods, CBD has become one of the most commonly used methods for the synthesis of chalcogenide-based photocatalytic materials because of its excellent controllability, uniformity, and affordability. For example, Wu et al. [47] prepared ZnO/ZnIn2S4 S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts by loading ZnIn2S4 onto ZnO using the CBD method, which were then used for the preparation of H2O2. As shown in Figs. 6(a) and (b) , in the photocatalyst sample (ZZS-20), ZnIn2S4 nanoparticles were uniformly loaded onto the ZnO surface, and the close contact formed in this manner was conducive to improving the photogenerated charge carrier migration efficiency (Fig. 6(c)). Moreover, the H2O2 yield of the sample (ZZS-20) was higher than that of pure ZnO (Fig. 6(d)), and it showed good photochemical stability after the cycling reaction (Figs. 6(e) and (f)). In another study, Michalec et al. [48] constructed SnO2/SnS2 S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts by coating SnO2 with SnS2 using the CBD method; the photoactivity and stability of SnS2 were effectively enhanced. In general, the CBD method is relatively mature and suitable for industrial synthesis. The deposited samples prepared by this method have compact grains. The CBD method has the advantages of being a simple process with high controllability and low cost. However, it also has some shortcomings, such as the difficulty in achieving local or selective deposition and a slow reaction rate. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a suitable preparation scheme for CBD to synthesize chalcogenide-based photocatalysts. 3.3 Precipitation Precipitation is a method for preparing solid photocatalysts and is characterized by adding precipitants to the solution and controlling the pH value to obtain homogeneous precipitates. This method can evenly mix and distribute the components of the catalyst, and the catalyst can then be loaded onto the carrier in the form of a package. Precipitation can be used to homogeneously and closely combine different forms of catalyst components under specific conditions. As shown in Fig. 7(a) , Zuifiqar et al. [49] used the coprecipitation method to dissolve MnO2 nanorods in a deionized water solution after ultrasonic treatment. Then, they mixed the resulting solution with another solution of thiourea dissolved in deionized water and controlled the pH value and temperature by centrifugation to obtain the precipitate. The core-shell structure was obtained after washing the dry MnO2@CdS S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst (MC). Fig. 7(b) shows that spherical CdS nanocomposites were deposited on the surface of the MnO2 nanotubes such that all the MnO2 nanotubes were uniformly covered by spherical CdS nanocomposites. The test results show that sample (MC-10) has good photocatalytic hydrogen production performance and excellent stability (Figs. 7(d) and (e)) because this core-shell structure with a tight interface preserves the strong redox ability of CdS as well as facilitates the formation of S-scheme heterojunctions at the interface. In general, the preparation of nanomaterials using the precipitation method has the advantages of a simple preparation process and uniform material composition. However, in the preparation process, attention should be paid to the rate of precipitant addition and other issues to prevent agglomeration or non-uniformity of the components. 3.4 In situ photochemical deposition The in situ photochemical deposition technique involves the preparation of semiconductor heterojunctions using optical radiation to excite the structure of in situ chemical substances and induce chemical reactions under specific conditions. This method uses light energy to prepare the semiconductor heterojunctions. Compared to the traditional photodeposition method, the in situ photochemical deposition method can obtain materials with good stability and no damage. When two semiconductor photocatalysts are in close contact, a heterojunction is formed. The spatial distribution of the photocatalysts in contact affects the activity of hydrogen evolution through photocatalysis. Parameters such as the composition and microstructure of semiconductor heterojunctions can be flexibly controlled via in situ photochemical deposition. For example, Lu et al. [50] prepared different MoO2-loaded CdS NR heterostructures (MCS) by selectively depositing MoO x S y onto CdS nanorods. Specifically, CdS NRs and (NH4)6Mo7O24-4H2O were dispersed in a 20% methanol/water solution, cleaned with argon after sonication to eliminate air, and irradiated with visible light for 3 h. The samples were washed and dried before sulfurization. During MCS preparation, MoS2 gradually diffused from the tip to the wall until the CdS NRs were completely covered (Figs. 8(a) and (b) ). In addition, the sample (2.5MCS) showed good photocatalytic activity and cycle stability in the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity test (Figs. 8(c) and (d)). The experiment showed that the distribution of MoS2 across the space at the tips of the CdS NRs resulted in a long photogenerated electron migration path, which became a key factor for the slow recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs (Fig. 8(e)). In conclusion, in situ photochemical deposition has obvious advantages, such as no need for external energy, and the use of light energy to activate the material can effectively reduce the contamination of the material surface. However, this also involves the use of light sources and has safety issues and gas consumption problems. Therefore, light source power and gas usage must be optimized during in situ photochemical deposition. 3.5 Electrospinning Electrospinning is commonly used to fabricate nanofibrous materials. In this process, a charged viscous polymer solution is accelerated in the electric field of a Taylor cone, forming a jet stream in the high-pressure electrostatic field, stretching, and finally curing the receiving device to form nanofibers. Electrospinning can be used to prepare nanofiber materials with various structures, including 1D nanostructures. 1D nanofibers, as nanostructured materials, are ideal structural materials for energy transmission because their structure can improve the specific surface area and facilitate the transmission of charge carriers along the 1D trajectory direction [51–53]. Ge et al. [57] used in situ electrospinning to synthesize 1D TiO2/CdS S-scheme nanofibers with well-distributed structures. Fig. 9(a) illustrates the preparation process of the TiO2/CdS well-distributed hybrid nanofibers. The precursor solutions used for the electrospinning were Cd(CH3COO)2, tetrabutyl titanate, polyvinylpyrrolidone, acetic acid, and ethanol. Moreover, a good distribution of CdS on the TiO2 surface was observed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) (Fig. 9(d)). In subsequent photocatalytic activity experiments, some samples exhibited excellent photocatalytic performance and good stability. In addition, in situ XPS and EPR analyses showed the formation of an S-scheme heterojunction between TiO2 and CdS. Nanofibers created by electrospinning possess complex porous configurations that can easily form close contacts between the photocatalysts, thereby facilitating the formation of heterojunctions. For example, Wang et al. [54] successfully fabricated an In2S3/Nb2O5 hybrid nanofiber photocatalyst by electrospinning Nb2O5 nanofibers and growing In2S3 nanosheets on their surfaces in situ. XPS and ESP tests and analyses confirmed the formation of an S-scheme heterojunction. In addition, some studies have shown that porous nanofiber photocatalysts have a significant effect on the degradation of environmental pollutants, such as organic compounds, providing an effective way to solve future environmental pollution problems [55,56]. In summary, to prepare high-performance photocatalysts, it is necessary to further study methods for fabricating nanofibrous materials with porous or hollow structures. Electrospinning is an effective method for expanding the morphology of chalcogenide photocatalysts. It has the advantages of low synthesis cost and high specific surface area of nanofibers, and it has great application potential in the field of photocatalysis. However, owing to the complex preparation device, which is easily affected by environmental conditions, some technical problems must still be overcome before the application scale can be further increased. 3.6 Other methods In addition to the abovementioned preparation methods, other methods such as self-assembly, oil bath, and in situ chemical bath deposition can be used to prepare chalcogenide-based heterojunctions. For example, self-assembly is a synthesis technique in which basic structural motifs (nanomaterials, molecules, etc.) spontaneously form ordered structures under the interactive forces between them. It is characterized by a fine degree of control during the preparation process and effective continuous deposition of different components. Li et al. [58] combined ZnCdS nanospheres (ZCS) with dibenzothiophene-group-modified g-C3N4 (DBTCN) and prepared a ZCS@DBTCN S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst via self-assembly, which showed rapid intramolecular and interfacial transfer of the photoexcited charge carriers. Additionally, Zhu et al. [59] in another study on the synthesis of Mo-modified ZnIn2S4-coated NiTiO3 microrods, used the self-assembly method to prepare porous NiTiO3 microrod precursors, which was conducive to the in situ growth of Mo-ZIS nanosheets on the precursors and the adsorption of multiple ions, thereby promoting the formation of a heterojunction. The oil bath method is a heating method that uses oil as a hot bath medium. This method aims to avoid direct heating, strictly and uniformly control the temperature, and reduce instability factors during the reaction of compounds. Xu et al. [60] synthesized SrTiO3/ZnIn2S4 composites by anchoring SrTiO3 nanoparticles to the surface of ZnIn2S4 with a silver-like structure using an oil bath method. This material exhibited ultrahigh photocatalytic activity for the degradation of methyl orange. In situ chemical bath deposition is a chemical process in which metal ions in solution are reduced and deposited on the surface of a substrate using reducing agents. This method has a high film-formation rate and can effectively complete the deposition on spherical substrates. Wang et al. [61] prepared a layered structure of TiO2@ZnIn2S4 core-shell hollow spheres by growing ZnIn2S4 nanosheets on the outer surface of TiO2 hollow spheres via in situ chemical bath deposition. This rational structural design effectively promoted the separation of useful photogenerated electrons and holes, resulting in excellent photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance. Other preparation methods, including ball milling, grinding, and microwave hydrothermal methods, are also used to prepare chalcogenide-based heterojunctions. 4 Applications Photocatalytic technology can convert green and renewable solar energy into chemical energy and has obvious development prospects. One of the major problems in the development of semiconductor photocatalysis is the improvement of catalytic efficiency [62]. The S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst effectively segregates photogenerated electron holes, which can effectively improve the photocatalytic performance and expand the development and application of photocatalytic technology in different fields [63–65]. Furthermore, photocatalysts made of metal-sulfide-based heterojunctions exhibit promising growth prospects for photocatalytic applications, attributed to their slim band gaps and varied structural forms [66,67]. Compared with some metal sulfides, metal selenides have a larger layer spacing and higher conductivity; therefore, they are also a highly efficient choice as catalysts for nitrogen fixation [68]. As shown in Fig. 10 , the applications of chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts in different photocatalytic reactions are briefly analyzed and discussed below. 4.1 Hydrogen evolution To meet the increasing demand for energy and to reduce the dependence on traditional non-renewable energy, many new energy sources have been explored to replace coal and oil, such as hydrogen energy, tidal power generation, wind power generation, biomass, and solar power. Among these, solar energy is a green, sustainable, and abundant energy source [69]. Along with solar energy, H2 has also attracted significant attention owing to its low carbonization properties and high combustion efficiency [70]. Photocatalytic technology for water decomposition can transform solar power into energy fuel for the production of H2; this technology is widely acclaimed for its potential as a renewable and environmentally friendly option [71–74]. In the realm of photocatalytic hydrogen generation, the performance of single-component photocatalytic systems is limited, and their hydrogen production efficiency is low. The selection of photocatalyst components with appropriate bandgap structures and the construction of heterojunctions can help enhance the activity of photocatalytic hydrogen production [75–77] and increase the possibility of achieving the degradation of chemical pollutants to promote the multifunctional application of hydrogen production [78]. Numerous studies have been undertaken to explore the effect of constructing S-scheme heterojunctions between photocatalysts on the performance of photocatalytic hydrogen production. For example, Cheng et al. [79] developed an inorganic-organic S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst by growing CdS and pyrene-alt-triphenylamine (PT) in situ. The supported 1%Pt cocatalyst and 2%CdS/PT catalyst showed a high hydrogen production rate of 9.28 mmol h−1 g−1, which was attributed to the high electron-hole separation efficiency and strong redox activity of the S-scheme heterojunction. In a separate study, Sun et al. [80] constructed an MnCo2S4/g-C3N4 S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst by combining g-C3N4 and MnCo2S4 with a suitable bandgap structure to achieve improved photocatalytic hydrogen production activity. An analysis of the UV-vis absorption and PL spectra revealed that MnCo2S4/g-C3N4 exhibited high visible light utilization and electron-hole separation efficiency under light irradiation. To form heterojunctions between the photocatalysts, it is usually necessary to select photocatalyst structures that can be in close contact with each other, such as 2D sheet structures and multidimensional hierarchical structures. These structures usually have many active sites and short carrier-transport distances, which provide good performance and application prospects for the study of H2 generation by photocatalysis [81]. Dai et al. [14] constructed a 2D nanosheet ZnWO4-ZnIn2S4 S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst. The exterior of the created composite photocatalyst, coated with nanosheets, showed a flower-like spherical structure, which combined to make ZnWO4 and ZnIn2S4 more closely bound together and contributed to the formation of a heterojunction, enhancing the interface charge migration (Figs. 11(a) and (b) ). The 2D nanosheet ZnWO4-ZnIn2S4 S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst showed good photocatalytic hydrogen evolution performance and cycling stability (Figs. 11(c–f)) in the H2 characterization test with methanol as a hole scavenger. To develop catalysts with excellent performance and stability for hydrogen production by photocatalytic hydrolysis, relevant studies have been conducted on the surface state of the catalysts and their reactivity to adsorption. Liu et al. [82] discovered that the surface-bound bridging hydroxyl (OHB) group of TiO2 has the ability to react with absorbed water, creating hydrated OHB groups, and its catalytic efficiency is directly linked to the quantity of hydrated OHB. Concurrently, the hydrated OHB group acts as a conduit for light-triggered h+ transfer, collaboratively facilitating the creation of •OH and •O2 ‒ radicals through the absorption of water. The experiments showed that the hydrophilicity of the catalyst surface was positively correlated with catalytic activity. The influence of surface characteristics on catalytic efficiency was further explored by Huang et al. [83]. In this study, the hydrogen production reaction of the Co9S8/TiO2 S-scheme heterojunction was studied using triethanolamine (TEOA) as a sacrificial agent. As shown in Figs. 12(a) and (b) , the H2 production rate of Co9S8/TiO2 can reach 3982 μmol g‒1 h‒1, which is 13.2 times that of pure TiO2, and Co9S8/TiO2 shows good cycling stability. XPS and Fourier transform infrared tests (Figs. 12(c–f)) revealed that the surface of Co9S8/TiO2 adsorbed more •OH radicals than pure TiO2, showing better hydrophilic properties. Moreover, Co-O-Ti chemical bonds were formed between semiconductors, which served as a conduit for transferring electrical charge and higher reaction sites and helped enhance the H2 evolution reaction performance. In conclusion, the selection of chalcogenides in heterojunctions can effectively improve hydrogen production efficiency. To achieve stable and efficient hydrogen production via photocatalytic hydrolysis, it is necessary to comprehensively consider the structures and surface properties of catalysts. 4.2 CO2 conversion With rapid industrialization, the use and development of fossil fuels have accelerated the emission of carbon dioxide, which has exacerbated the greenhouse effect and the progression of climate change. Therefore, the efficient use of solar energy to convert atmospheric CO2 into fuels or industrial raw materials has become a popular research topic [84–87]. However, CO2 is a linear molecule with very good thermodynamic stability, and the C=O bond has a bond energy of 750 kJ mol‒1; therefore, it is relatively difficult to break, which limits its ability to undergo reductive transformation [88]. Compared with traditional CO2 reduction technologies, photocatalysis is green and sustainable, and the reaction conditions are mild [89]. Common modification methods for improving the performance of photocatalysts include adjusting their structural properties [24,90,91] and the structure of heterojunctions [92,93]. CO2 reduction yields CO and hydrocarbons, which are usually more valuable than the CO in the reaction (Fig. 13 ). Chalcogenides such as metal sulfides and metal selenides are considered promising photocatalysts for CO2 reduction because of their appropriate band gap energies and unique band structures [94,95]. In addition, the photocorrosion problem often encountered with chalcogenide photocatalysts can be effectively solved by constructing heterojunction structures. Zhao et al. [19] synthesized an S-scheme heterojunction Bi2S3/BiVO4/Mn0.5Cd0.5S-DETA (BS/BVO/MCS) photocatalyst using an in situ hydrothermal growth method. BiVO4 as an oxidation catalyst in this heterojunction consumes excess holes and improves the photocatalyst stability. In addition, diethylenetriamine (DETA) promoted the growth of Mn0.5Cd0.5S-DETA on the surface of BiVO4. BS/BVO/MCS exhibited better photocatalytic CO2 reduction activity and good photostability. Considering the effect of the effective contact area in heterojunctions on charge transfer, 1D and 2D materials are commonly used to build core-shell structures [96]. Effective and close interface contact can improve the light absorption ability of the heterojunction and shorten the length of the electron transport channel. Moreover, it provides abundant active sites for the photocatalytic reduction of CO2. For example, Xiong et al. [97] prepared an MoO3−x @ZnIn2S4 S-scheme heterojunction with a core-shell structure for enhancing the photocatalytic CO2 reduction activity. ZnIn2S4 nanosheets were grown in situ on MoO3−x needle crystals by solvothermal reduction to construct a core-shell structure (Fig. 14(a) ) with tight interface contact. The close contact at the heterojunction interface is advantageous for charge transfer during photocatalytic reactions. MoO3−x @ZnIn2S4 exhibited better photocatalytic activity and stability than ZnIn2S4 and exhibited high CH4 selectivity (Figs. 14(b) and (c)). In addition, the local surface plasmon resonance effect induced by the oxygen vacancy in MoO3−x generates numerous high-energy hot electrons, significantly raising the surface temperature of the catalyst and speeding up charge transfer and CO2 adsorption and desorption, and exhibits high CO2 reduction efficiency (Figs. 14(d) and (e)) at high temperatures. 4.3 Organic transformations Significant research has been carried out on organic matter transformations. Considering the current interest in green development, photocatalytic organic conversion has become a research hotspot, given its advantages of mild reaction conditions, high conversion selectivity, reduction of side reactions, consumption, and pollution during the reaction [98]. As an environmentally friendly organic synthesis method, photocatalytic organic conversion has contributed to significant progress in different photocatalytic redox reactions, such as the conversion of alkenes to enols, ketones, and aldehydes and the hydrogenation reaction of carboxylic acids. In addition, coupled photoredox and hydrogen evolution reactions have attracted much attention. The specific transformation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde has significant industrial value. Photocatalytic conversion technology can convert benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde in the gas phase using semiconductor catalysts while simultaneously using the protons generated in the conversion process of benzaldehyde to prepare hydrogen, which can improve the hydrogen generation rate while ensuring high selectivity. However, there are many difficulties associated with semiconductor catalytic systems, and the recombination of charge carriers often plays a key role in the catalytic effect. In this regard, in addition to the construction of the S-scheme heterojunction, the transfer and separation efficiencies of charge carriers can be further improved by cocatalyst modification [99]. For example, Yang et al. [100] synthesized a core-shell-shaped MIL-88B(Fe)/ZIS S-scheme heterojunction (CMZIS) by depositing a sulfur-rich amorphous CoS1+x co-catalyst on the surface. The addition of the sulfur-rich CoS1+x cocatalyst improved the capability of the heterojunction to absorb visible light (Fig. 15(a) ), and the synergistic interaction of MIL-88B(Fe) and CoS1+x effectively improved the efficiency of the separation and utilization of photogenerated carriers in the heterojunction (Figs. 15(b) and (c)). CMZIS showed good photocatalytic activity in the photocatalytic performance test: the hydrogen evolution rate and benzaldehyde production rate were 3164.9 μmol g−1 h−1 and 3417.8 μmol g−1 h−1, which are 7.9 and 8.1 times higher than that of pure ZIS, respectively (Fig. 15(d)), with a high selectivity for benzaldehyde formation (> 99%). The CoS1+x cocatalyst played a significant role in attracting and accumulating electrons during the photocatalytic reaction after illumination, and an efficient synergistic photoredox reaction was achieved by cooperation with the S-scheme heterojunction. This principle is illustrated in Fig. 15(e). To select materials for improving the catalytic activity and selectivity of photocatalytic oxidation reactions, metal-organic framework compounds (MOFs) and covalent organic frameworks (COFs), in addition to the cocatalyst modification method, are being widely studied [101,102]. MOFs and COFs have large surface areas and provide more active sites for the catalytic process. UiO-66-NH2 (U6N) is a zirconium-based MOF with high stability and visible light response characteristics and is a suitable MOF material for photocatalytic reactions. Liu et al. [102] modified the surface of U6N with CdS nanoparticles to form an S-scheme heterojunction of MOF/inorganic composites with core-shell structures. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) and EPR technology confirmed the mechanism of the conversion of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde in sunlight. The photoproduction oxidizing reaction of benzyl alcohol and U6N is divided into two steps, depending on the intermediate product: First, α-C oxidation of benzyl alcohol occurs on the generated intermediates, •CH(OH)Ph and •CH(OH)Ph, followed by further oxidation to yield benzaldehyde. Second, the H+ generated in this reaction reacts with the photogenerated electrons in CdS to produce H2. This heterojunction exhibited 99% selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde with a hydrogen production of 630 μmol g‒1 h‒1 while maintaining stable photocatalytic activity over multiple cycles. 4.4 H2O2 production H2O2 is recognized as an eco-friendly oxidant with extensive applications in chemical synthesis and medical science. There are various industrial techniques for the preparation of H2O2, of which the most common and widely used is the anthraquinone oxidation method. However, the process of anthraquinone oxidation is complex, which inevitably has many shortcomings, such as high energy consumption, and the solvent system produces toxic pollutants and safety hazards. Therefore, it is necessary to find a suitable and environmentally friendly method for the efficient production of H2O2. Photocatalytic technology is a promising H2O2 production method owing to the abundance of raw materials and environmental sustainability [103–105]. It primarily includes two processes: an H2O oxidation reaction and a single or double electron reduction reaction to synthesize H2O2. The most commonly used photocatalysts are TiO2, g-C3N4, and BiVO4 [106–110]. However, owing to the low utilization rate of visible light and self-burning, as well as the agglomeration of H2O2 in the absence of sacrificial agents, these catalysts exhibit reduced activity, thereby restricting the overall generation of H2O2. As a typical II-VI semiconductor, CdS has a strong visible-light response and photoexcitation yield, a high negative conduction band, and excellent catalytic activity, which are often used to enhance the photocatalytic production of H2O2. However, unmodified CdS exhibits the disadvantages of photocorrosion and easy charge recombination, resulting in increased contaminants and decreased efficiency during photocatalysis. To this end, heterojunctions and surface modifications are usually constructed to improve the surface stability and inhibit photocorrosion [111,112]. For example, Ghoreishian et al. [113] prepared a Bi2S3@CdS@RGO ternary S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst by wrapping reduced graphene oxide (RGO) on a Bi2S3@CdS composite as a key structure to inhibit CdS photocorrosion and rapid surface reorganization. Such ternary composite heterojunctions exhibit better visible light responses in optoelectronic tests (Fig. 16(a) ), and RGO acts as an electron quencher, improving charge transfer and extending carrier lifetime (Fig. 16(b)). Lai et al. [114] studied CdS/K2Ta2O6 by designing and constructing heterojunction catalysts to improve the photocatalytic activity and photostability. A flower-shaped CdS/K2Ta2O6 S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst was constructed by growing CdS nanocrystals in situ on the oxygen vacancies of K2Ta2O6. The H2O2 yield was 160.89 μmol g‒1 h‒1, which is higher than that for many advanced CDS-based photocatalysts. Moreover, CdS/K2Ta2O6 exhibits better photostability than pure CdS (Figs. 17(a) and (b) ). With the development of photocatalytic production of H2O2, the use of photogenerated H2O2 has attracted considerable attention. Wang et al. [108] successfully established an S-scheme heterojunction by uniformly attaching protonated g-C3N4 to the surface of transition metal sulfide spherical α-MnS. Single or double electron reduction of O2 to H2O2 was achieved using electrons from the MnS components without the use of an electron donor or pure oxygen. The H2O2 yield of the protonated g-C3N4/MnS heterojunction reached 209.4 μmol L‒1 h‒1, and the photogenerated H2O2 could be efficiently utilized by in situ oxidation. In another study, Xu et al. [115] modified CdSe quantum dots by co-doping with K, P, and N, which significantly improved the carrier recombination efficiency. The prepared CdSe/KPN-HCP (K, P, and n-co-doped hollow carbon polyhedra (KPN-HCP)) exhibited excellent photocatalytic performance. 4.5 N2 fixation N2 is an odorless and colorless gas at room temperature and pressure, and while it makes up 78% of the air, it is inaccessible to most organisms because of its high stability [116–118]. The Haber-Bosch process has been used for large-scale industrial nitrogen fixation to generate gaseous NH3 since the early 20th century. The catalytic conversion of N2 to NH3 still holds great potential for applications in many fields. Nonetheless, the traditional Haber-Bosch reaction conditions are extremely stringent, and the energy required for the reaction is provided by fossil fuels, which results in CO2 emissions [119] and affects the development of N2 utilization research to a certain extent. Therefore, the development of environmentally friendly photocatalytic nitrogen fixation technologies has attracted significant attention [120,121]. Despite the promising development of photocatalytic nitrogen fixation, the N≡N bond is very stable and difficult to break under many environmental conditions. Moreover, common semiconductor photocatalysts have the shortcomings of fast recombination of photogenerated carriers and few active sites. Thus, they are unable to provide enough electrons to dissociate nitrogen bonds and activate N2 effectively. To improve the nitrogen fixation efficiency of photocatalysts, different techniques have been proposed, such as controlling defects or introducing vacancies to increase the number of active sites [122,123], doping elements, and forming S-scheme heterojunctions to improve photogenerated carrier recombination [124]. Copper sulfide, a typical p-type semiconductor, has broad prospects for photocatalytic applications owing to its narrow bandgap, complex crystal structure, and high negative conduction band potential. Zuo et al. [122] used negative ion exchange and hydrothermal methods to perform the in situ growth of oxygen vacancy (OV)-type TiO2 and Cu7S4 on a copper mesh (CM) and prepared an OV-TiO2@Cu7S4/CM S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst via calcination modification. Calcination increased the specific surface area of the catalyst, which in turn provided additional reaction locations for light and enhanced the capacity of the material to absorb light (Figs. 18(a) and (b) ). In addition, the oxygen vacancies in TiO2 yielded abundant local electrons and adjacent defect states, which enhanced the adsorption ability of N2 molecules. Moreover, the synergistic effect of surface defects and heterostructures effectively improved photogenerated charge carrier recombination, and OV-TiO2@Cu7S4/CM showed excellent photocatalytic activity and nitrogen fixation efficiency (Figs. 18(c) and (d)). In another research work, Bariki et al. [123] designed a sulfur-rich defect UiO-66(−NH2)/CuInS2 S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst (UN66/CuInS2). UN66 was integrated with layered CuInS2 nanosheets via a low-temperature synthesis. The layered form of CuInS2 in the heterostructure provided a large specific surface area and many surface-active sites, which were conducive to the adsorption of gas molecules. The UN66/CuInS2 photocatalyst exhibited a 5.9-fold greater N2 reduction performance than that of bare UN66. 4.6 Degradation With the growth of modern industrialization, the severity of environmental pollution has escalated primarily because of the presence of organic pollutants and inorganic heavy metals [125]. To solve the problem of environmental pollutants, photocatalytic technologies have attracted considerable attention, including metal oxides [78], metal sulfides [42], selenides [115], and organic photocatalysts [126]. In addition, according to different sources of pollutants, there are also corresponding scenarios of photocatalyst research progress [127,128]. Among them, chalcogenides have become a hot research topic in the realm of photocatalytic degradation owing to their excellent performance and suitable band structure. The Fenton process is a classic technology used to degrade organic pollutants. The photo-Fenton process, developed by combining photochemistry with the Fenton process, has great potential for the photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants because of its good oxidation performance and utilization of solar energy. Moreover, sulfides such as MoS2 can also effectively promote the Fenton reaction as photocatalysts [129]. However, the heterogeneous photo-Fenton system has high difficulty and low efficiency in recovering powder catalysts, which carries the risk of secondary environmental pollution and harm to human health [130]. Loading a catalyst onto a three-dimensional support can increase the efficiency of catalyst recovery [131]. Gao et al. [132] prepared composite sponges by loading MoS2/Bi2S3/BiVO4 S-scheme heterojunctions (MBB) onto lignosulfonate (LS)-modified polyvinyl alcohol sponges (PLS). After the loading sponge was modified by LS, its affinity for organic pollutants was improved, and a synergy between sponge surface adsorption and photo-Fenton degradation was realized (Fig. 19(a) ). An analysis of the main active substances in the degradation of norfloxacin via the PLS-MBB photo-Fenton reaction using five quenching agents revealed that the main active substances in the reaction system were electrons and holes (Fig. 19(b)). The photogenerated electron e(MoS2) and photogenerated hole h+(BiVO4) on MoS2 and BiVO4 could redox O2 and H2O to •O2 ‒ and •OH, respectively, and e(MoS2) could improve the efficiency of the Fe3+/Fe2+ conversion reaction, thereby maintaining the steadiness of the photo-Fenton reaction. Finally, h+(BiVO4), •O2 ‒, and •OH participated in the reaction to complete the degradation of organic pollutants. In addition, PLS-MBB achieved a 68.5% H2O2 to •OH conversion efficiency, showing excellent catalytic efficiency against the Fenton reaction (Fig. 19(c)). In recent years, the issue of antibiotic contamination has escalated in severity, with refractory antibiotics slowly accumulating in soil and water. Tetracycline, the most widely used low-cost broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent, has been detected in surface water and groundwater. Therefore, the development of environmentally friendly and efficient antibiotic degradation technologies is essential [133]. Zhang et al. [21] prepared a CuInS2/g-C3N4 S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst by loading CuInS2 QDs onto g-C3N4 via a solvothermal method. When the amount of CuInS2 was suitable, the degradation rate of tetracycline by CuInS2/g-C3N4 was 3.4 times that of pure g-C3N4. 4.7 Sterilization Bacteria exist in every part of human life, and many types of bacteria are highly infectious, posing a serious threat to human health [134–136]. The long-term use of antibiotics to treat bacterial infections causes bacteria to develop drug resistance and greatly reduces the efficiency of sterilization. Moreover, current sterilization technologies are relatively complex. In recent years, inorganic composite materials, such as semiconductor photocatalysts, have received extensive attention [137–139]. Under light irradiation, photocatalysts can produce active substances with strong sterilization effects and enter bacterial cells for oxidation [140,141]. This performance is related to the photoelectric properties of the photocatalysts. Therefore, constructing heterojunction structures between photocatalysts to improve carrier separation efficiency is a promising strategy. MoS2 is a p-type semiconductor that has shown good photocatalytic activity for the degradation of organic pollutants and the reduction of heavy metals because of its narrow bandgap, good visible light absorption efficiency, and high electron mobility [132]. In addition, MoS2 has the characteristics of low cytotoxicity [142]. Liu et al. [143] used an iron-containing metal-organic skeleton, NH2-MIL101(Fe), as a structural scaffold for the growth of MoS2 nanosheets, generated flower-like NH2-MIL-101(Fe)@MoS2 microspheres (F101@MoS2), and deposited ZnO quantum dots (QDs) on the external surface of F101@MoS2. Ternary F101@MoS2/ZnO composites were prepared, and a heterojunction structure was successfully constructed. The F101@MoS2/ZnO composite exhibited excellent bactericidal and antibacterial efficiencies under visible-light irradiation because of the enhanced efficiency of superoxide radical generation through the reduction of oxygen by photogenerated electrons (Figs. 20(a–d) ). In another study, Chen et al. [144] synthesized nano-heterojunctions of MoS2/SnO2 by a hydrothermal method. After the construction of the S-scheme heterojunction, MoS2/SnO2 exhibited an enhanced photogenerated carrier separation rate and excellent bactericidal and antibacterial activities against Escherichia coli. In general, there are still some problems with photocatalytic sterilization technology, such as low sterilization efficiency, complex operation, and performance that does not meet the conditions for production. The specific photocatalytic bactericidal mechanisms require further study. Photocatalysis has a long way to go in the field of disinfection. Table 1 summarizes the catalytic efficiencies of chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts for photocatalytic applications. 5 Frontier characterization technique To design chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts with excellent photocatalysis capability, appropriate photocatalysts must be chosen to form heterojunctions, design catalyst morphologies with more active sites, and explore the coupling between charge transfer and redox reactions. To analyze photocatalytic light absorption, the effect of the catalyst surface morphology on the catalytic efficiency and charge transfer pathway, among others, must be characterized after the preparation of the photocatalyst. Some characterization techniques are discussed in this section. 5.1 In-situ XPS XPS is widely used to study the composition and state of chemical elements and the content and concentration of elements on a sample surface [145–147]. Moreover, the electron gain and loss can be determined from the change in the electron binding energy. Therefore, the direction of charge transfer and the reason for charge transfer enhancement in the heterojunction can be analyzed using XPS [148,149]. In situ XPS (ISXPS) is performed when the sample is exposed to light during a conventional XPS test. When an S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst is irradiated by a light source, RP accepts electrons from OP because the Fermi level of RP is larger than that of OP, resulting in an increase in the elemental electron binding energy of OP and a decrease in its electron binding energy. In general, ISXPS is used in conjunction with other characterization methods because the observed binding energies of ISXPS are subtle and cannot clearly determine the heterojunction type. Moreover, the electron gain and loss can be determined by the change in the electron binding energy in conventional XPS. Therefore, the direction of charge transfer and the reason for charge transfer enhancement in the heterojunction can be analyzed using XPS [97,150–152]. For example, Zhu et al. [153] employed ISXPS, ex situ XPS characterization, and contact potential difference (CPD) measurements to confirm the S-scheme mechanism of CdS/RF photocatalysts. CdS/RF composites were constructed by the in situ growth of CdS nanoparticles on resorcinol-formaldehyde (RF) spheres. XPS spectra of pure RF, CdS, and CdS/RF composites revealed that the binding energies of C 1s C–O bonds in CdS/RF samples shifted by 0.2 eV toward lower values relative to RF, while in contrast, the binding energies of S 2p and Cd 3d in CdS/RF samples shifted by 0.2 eV toward higher values relative to CdS (Figs. 21(a–c) ). The direction of electron transfer at the two semiconductor contact interfaces is related to their work functions, and their CPDs are positively related to the work functions. The CPD measurement of the CdS/RF samples showed that the CPD of RF was higher than the measured CPD of CdS (Fig. 21(d)). Thus, electrons flow from CdS to RF after CdS is loaded onto the RF, forming an internal electric field at the interface, and the point field is directed from CdS to RF. After illumination, the C 1s binding energies were positively shifted, and the S 2p and Cd 3d binding energies were negatively shifted in the CdS/RF sample, indicating a shift of photogenerated electrons from RF to CdS. The preceding examination revealed that the charge transfer in the CdS/RF heterojunction adhered to the S-scheme mechanism, as depicted in Fig. 21(e). 5.2 In situ EPR Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) technology can be used to detect unpaired electrons directly, in situ, and nondestructively and to provide information on electron, orbital, and nuclear microscales. After light excitation, the photocatalysts generate a variety of reactive free radicals, which subsequently undergo redox reactions. Tracking and characterizing the species and concentrations of these free radicals are of great significance for exploring reaction mechanisms. Compared to conventional free-radical identification techniques, EPR has more advantages in detecting the species and yield of free radicals during photocatalysis [154–156]. In situ EPR can represent the electronic state of the photocatalyst more intuitively, monitor the transfer of photogenerated charge during the photocatalytic reaction in real time, and exhibit better selectivity for the qualitative and quantitative testing of different free radicals [157,158]. Moreover, trapping agents are added to the reaction to capture free radicals, which can be used to study the mechanism of photocatalytic enhancement and the redox ability of the catalyst [159]. In addition, when determining the heterojunction charge-transfer path type, EPR can detect the existence of •OH and •O2 – radicals in the reaction system, which indirectly indicates that the heterojunction is an S-scheme heterojunction. Lee et al. [150] rationally coupled 2D BIO nanosheets with 1D CdS nanorods to produce CdS/BIO S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts. In-situ EPR characterization was performed on the BIO, CdS, and CdS-10/BIO samples using DMPO as the spin trap. On the CdS-10/BIO sample, no signal of DMPO-•O2 – or DMPO-•OH was observed in the dark, whereas a distinct signal was detected under irradiation (Figs. 22(a) and (b) ). Moreover, the DMPO-•O2 – signal of CdS-10/BIO was much stronger than that of CdS, and the DMPO-•O2 – signal of BIO was almost indistinguishable. Meanwhile, the DMPO-•OH intensity of CdS-10/BIO was significantly higher than that of BIO, whereas the DMPO-•OH signal of CdS was absent. This indicates that the CdS-10/BIO sample produced more •OH and •O2 – reactive species than BIO or CdS and had a better redox capacity. It can be inferred that in the CdS/BIO heterojunction, the photogenerated electrons are transferred to the CB of CdS, and the holes are transferred to the VB of BIO. In addition, the creation of these entities indirectly supports the participation of the S-scheme charge-transfer mechanism in the formulated photocatalysts (Fig. 22(c)). 5.3 In situ DRIFTS DRIFTS is an analytical technique used to characterize the interaction between the surface of solid materials and gases, and its characteristics of high sensitivity and nondestructive testing can help effectively study the surface structure and chemical composition of materials [160,161]. DRIFTS allows researchers to study heterogeneous gas-phase reactions under actual reaction conditions. With the help of DRIFTS, important information on the interaction between the reactants and the catalyst surface, as well as the adsorption kinetics, can be obtained, which helps understand the catalytic mechanism more deeply. DRIFTS works by measuring the infrared light signal reflected from the material surface; therefore, it can characterize information such as adsorption phenomena and chemical reactions on the material surface. DRIFTS frequently serves to analyze the surface chemistry and molecular architecture of photocatalysts. In situ DRIFTS can detect ongoing chemical reactions in real time [162–165] and can be used to detect the intermediates involved in photocatalytic reactions. It can determine the types of intermediates in the reaction and detect the changes in intermediates and reaction paths in real time, which helps explain reactions involving electrons [164]. In situ DRIFTS is a common technique for studying the mechanism of photocatalytic CO2 reactions. Shao et al. [166] fabricated a NiS@Ta2O5 S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst by assembling electrospun Ta2O5 nanofibers and NiS nanosheets using an electric spin-coupled ion exchange strategy. Owing to the formation of an S-scheme heterojunction, NiS@Ta2O5 exhibited improved photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance. In addition, the interaction between CO2 and the sample was studied using temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD), which showed that the sample had good CO2 adsorption and CO desorption abilities (Figs. 23(a) and (b) ). To investigate the mechanism by which NiS@Ta2O5 catalyzes the CO2 reduction reaction, Shao et al. [166] examined the in situ DRIFTS spectra of Ta2O5 and 20NSTO. As shown in Fig. 23(d), the peaks of *CO2 and m-CO3 2‒ gradually increased with increasing irradiation time. In addition, an absorption peak near 1592 cm‒1, whose intensity increased with increased radiation time, appeared, indicating that *COOH is a key intermediate involved in converting CO2 into CO or CH4. By comparing Figs. 23(c) and (d), a new peak corresponding to HCO3 ‒ was observed near 1415 cm‒1, and a peak corresponding to *CHO was observed near 1094 cm‒1, both of which are essential intermediates for the photoreduction of CO2 to CO and CH4. Therefore, it can be inferred that the reaction path of 20NSTO in CO2 is CO2 → *CO2→ *COOH → *CO → CO/CH4. Similarly, Zhang et al. [167] conducted an extensive examination of the intermediates produced during the reduction of CO2 using an In4SnS8/Cs3Bi2Br9 S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst (ISS/CBB) through in situ DRIFTS (Fig. 24 ). After exposing ISS/CBB to the CO2/H2O gas mixture to reach the adsorption equilibrium point, the intensity of the CO2 ‒ substance absorption peak on the ISS/CBB catalyst was observed by in situ DRIFTS, and CO2 ‒ was considered to be a key intermediate for CO2 reduction. The rate of CO2 ‒ generation is considered essential for photocatalytic CO2 reduction. 5.4 Fs-TA To delve deeper into the enhancement of the photocatalytic efficiency of semiconductor photocatalysts, it is crucial to examine their charge-carrier transfer dynamics. Because the timescale of carrier transport is often between femtoseconds (fs) and picoseconds (ps), it is necessary to monitor this process using spectra with sufficient temporal resolution. Femtosecond transient absorption (Fs-TA) spectroscopy, which combines femtosecond time-resolved pump detection and differential absorption spectroscopy, is an important technique for studying ultrafast dynamics. Specifically, by measuring the signal intensity of the probe pulse when the sample pump pulse is irradiated and not irradiated, the change in the quantity of charge carriers in the excited state can be obtained. The relaxation dynamics of the charge carriers from the excited state to the ground state can be obtained by analyzing the differential absorption spectrum of the sample. Therefore, fs-TA is an important technique for determining the reaction mechanisms of photocatalytic systems [102,168,169]. In conclusion, fs-TA plays a crucial role in analyzing the electron transfer routes within the dynamics of photogenerated carriers. Cheng et al. [170] prepared a CdS/pyrene-alt-difluorinated benzothiadiazole S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst (CPDB) and used fs-TA spectroscopy to demonstrate the transient transfer of photogenerated charges in the S-scheme heterojunction (Figs. 25(a–d) ). The fs-TA spectra show that after the pure CdS sample was excited by the pump light, a negative peak belonging to the ground-state bleaching signal (GSB) appeared at 510 nm, reflecting the excitation of ground-state electrons to the excited state. In addition, the CPDB sample showed a negative peak at 710 nm in the TA spectrum at approximately 500 fs, which was not detected in the spectra of the pure CdS and PDB samples. Moreover, the wavelength of this peak aligns with the energy variance between the CB minimum of CdS and the highest occupied orbital of PDB, indicating the movement of electrons from CdS to PDB at the interface of the heterojunction. This provides direct evidence in support of the S-scheme charge-transfer pathway. Similarly, Xu et al. [171] prepared a TiO2/Ce2S3 S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst to promote the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline. The fs-TA spectra show that the TiO2/Ce2S3 sample (TC5) has an extended interfacial charge-transfer lifetime (43 ns). Specifically, a clear negative peak was observed for TC5 at 645 nm, corresponding to electron/hole recombination (Figs. 26(a) and (b) ). Moreover, by comparing the transient absorption kinetic trajectories of TiO2 and TC5 at 645 nm, it can be inferred that fast electron trapping and timely charge separation are the reasons for the inhibition of electron-hole recombination (Fig. 26(c)). 5.5 Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) KPFM as an electrostatic force microscopy technique, can not only scan the nanoscale surface of a sample but also provide quantitative results of the local surface potential distribution. The potential distribution on the sample surface is represented in pictures. Therefore, KPFM is often used to study the distribution of photogenerated charges on semiconductor photocatalyst surfaces. Moreover, the process of moving photogenerated electrons can be traced by detecting the difference in the photovoltage on the photocatalyst surface, which makes KPFM a key tool for verifying the charge-transfer process in S-scheme heterojunctions [79,172–174]. Li et al. [58] combined ZnCdS nanospheres (ZCS) with dibenzothiophene group-modified g-C3N4 (DBTCN) through self-assembly to prepare a ZCS@DBTCN S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst and performed in situ KPFM imaging of the material. ZCS@DBTCN exhibits enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity, and this enhanced performance is inseparable from the interfacial charge separation through the S-scheme heterojunction. Figs. 27(a‒c) show the morphology of the 7ZCS@DBTCN sample and its surface potential under light and dark conditions. The height of the ZCS nanospheres and thickness of the DBTCN nanosheets were confirmed by image analysis (Fig. 27(c)). In addition, as shown in Fig. 27(d), the difference in surface potential between ZCS and DBTCN under dark conditions was 160 mV, indicating that there was an internal electric field at the interface between ZCS and DBTCN, which was directed from ZCS to DBTCN. The presence of the S-scheme heterojunction mechanism was successfully demonstrated by the increased surface potential of ZCS and the decreased surface potential of DBTCN under light conditions compared to dark conditions. Liu et al. [175] constructed a perylene tetracarboxylic Zn (II)/Bi2WO6 S-scheme heterojunction (Zn-PTC/Bi2WO6). KPFM was used to study the internal electric field and potential at the interface between Zn-PTC and Bi2WO6, and the transfer path of the photogenerated electrons from Bi2WO6 to Zn-PTC was confirmed by detecting the change in the surface potential, which aligns with the S-scheme mechanism for charge transfer. 5.6 Density functional theory (DFT) DFT serves as a computational technique used to analyze the electronic structures of multiple electronic systems. DFT plays a significant role in the study of photocatalysis, particularly in understanding the mechanisms of photocatalytic reactions [176,177]. In the design of heterojunction photocatalysts, the selected semiconductors cause a difference in the Fermi level and work function, which leads to the redistribution of charge carriers and the creation of interfacial electric fields at the interface of the heterojunction. Therefore, based on the determined work function and the alteration in the electron density, the direction of the interfacial electric field can be inferred, which significantly aids in elucidating the charge transfer process in the S-scheme [178]. For example, Xiao et al. [179] used DFT calculations and work function measurements to provide an in-depth explanation of the S-scheme charge-transfer mechanism in a hollow core-shell g-C3N4@ZnIn2S4 S-scheme heterostructure (HCN@ZIS). DFT calculations were employed to examine the band configuration, state density, and charge transfer mechanism at the heterojunction interfaces of HCN, ZIS, and HCN@ZIS. Specifically, HCN and ZIS were represented as indirect band gap semiconductors. The simulated band structure shows that the band gaps of HCN and ZIS are 2.08 and 1.95 eV, respectively (Figs. 28(a) and (b) ). The HCN@ZIS band structure with a dense band distribution resulting from interfacial reactions indicates that electrons exhibit greater ease of transitioning between different energy levels (Fig. 28(c)). The mean distribution of the charge density on the z-axis directly confirms the reallocation of the charge density at the interface of the heterojunction. The electrons on the HCN move to the ZIS through the heterojunction interface, leaving holes on the HCN side, thereby creating an internal electric field at the interface (Fig. 28(d)). Moreover, the differential charge density simulated by the HCN@ZIS heterojunction geometry model more directly confirms the above conclusion (Fig. 28(e)), where the yellow and blue areas symbolize the gathering and reduction of free electrons, respectively, indicating that it is favorable for excited electrons to migrate from the HCN layer through the interface with the ZIS. The band positions and charge transfer of HCN and ZIS were simulated based on theoretical calculations, and the results are shown in Fig. 28(f). The electrons in the CB of ZIS have the potential to recombine with holes in the VB of HCN.
