This special charge-transfer mechanism confirms the successful construction of the HCN@ZIS S-scheme heterojunction. In another study, Dai et al. [180] also used DFT calculations to verify the band structure and state density of the CdLa2S4/ZnIn2S4 S-scheme heterojunction; at the internal interface of the heterojunction, the S, La, and In atoms functioned as bridges for electron transfer. DFT calculations were performed to estimate the work functions of CdLa2S4 and ZnIn2S4. Briefly, the work functions along the z-axis of CdLa2S4 with a surface of (100) and ZnIn2S4 with a surface of (001) are 5.67 and 4.38 eV, respectively. The difference in the work functions of the two semiconductors indicates that when the two contacts form the interface of the heterojunction, the charge movement direction from ZnIn2S4 to CdLa2S4 at the interface provides important proof for inferring the composition of the heterojunction in the S-scheme. Theoretical simulations and in situ characterization techniques provide insights into the unique S-scheme heterojunction mechanism. In conclusion, in situ XPS provides information on the variation in the electron density of the photocatalyst; however, it has a low resolution in the lateral space and can monitor the electronic state of samples and study the electron transfer process by observing the generation and disappearance of active substances. However, in-situ EPR is limited to the detection of paramagnetic samples. In addition, KPFM can be used to intuitively clarify the transfer of photogenerated electrons to the photocatalyst surface. The disadvantages of KPFM are that the imaging range is small, the scanning rate is slow, and the probe is significantly affected. At the same time, integrating in situ characterization with fs-TA spectroscopy is essential for a more thorough examination of charge transfer at the S-scheme heterojunction interface. The S-scheme heterojunction is verified by in situ XPS observations of changes in binding energy, detection of trapped radicals from in situ EPR studies, and analysis of interfacial charge states by KPFM and fs-TA after heterojunction formation. These observations, combined with DFT simulations, can help understand the S-scheme charge-transfer mechanism. 6 Conclusions Chalcogenides have attracted considerable attention because of their selective diversity, narrow bandgaps, and good reducibility. However, single-component chalcogenide photocatalysts typically exhibit fast carrier recombination and severe photocorrosion. Therefore, S-scheme heterojunctions constructed by combining chalcogenides with other semiconductors can effectively solve these problems. This review describes the latest progress in the development of chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts and their varied uses across different fields, and discusses the use of characterization techniques, such as in situ characterization, to investigate complex electron transfer mechanisms. Compared with single-component photocatalysts with low carrier separation efficiency and poor redox ability, the S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst combines the benefits of the two semiconductor components, and its distinctive charge transfer process significantly boosts the spatial segregation efficiency of charge carriers, thereby exhibiting improved redox properties. In addition, chalcogenide-based photocatalysts are favored because of their variety of species, wide range of visible-light effects, and tunable bandgaps. Therefore, the combination of chalcogenides with other suitable semiconductors for preparing S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts has great potential for development. Chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts have outstanding applications in the fields of energy and environmental protection, including photocatalytic hydrogen generation, CO2 transformation, organic change, H2O2 production, nitrogen fixation, degradation, and sterilization. Despite significant advancements in the research on chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts, additional research is required for their broad application. Based on this, we make the following observations: (1) The photogeneration of electron-hole pairs after the photoexcitation of the semiconductor photocatalyst indicates that the photocatalyst participates in both oxidation and reduction. At present, most photocatalysts are used only for their oxidation or reduction abilities, which means that the photogenerated electrons or holes that do not participate in the reaction become useless electrons or holes, hindering the advancement of the photocatalytic redox reaction. Recently, progress has been made in photocatalytic redox reactions, such as the photocatalytic decomposition of H2O coupled with organic oxidation for oxidative degradation and hydrogen production, photocatalytic production of H2O2 coupled with organic oxidation for in situ degradation of organic pollutants, and photocatalytic reduction and nitrogen fixation of CO2 coupled with organic oxidation. Therefore, coupling strongly reducing chalcogenides with strongly oxidizing organic semiconductors to construct S-scheme heterojunctions is an effective way to enhance the overall redox capacity of heterojunction photocatalysts. (2) Excellent light absorption is necessary for high-performance heterojunction photocatalysts. By combining chalcogenides with organic semiconductors having large specific surface areas and designing organic semiconductors into controllable shapes, such as hollow and porous, the refraction and scattering of incident light can be increased, and the light-absorption ability of the catalyst can be effectively enhanced. In addition, surface modification engineering, for example, doping with heavy metal nanoparticles, such as silver, can generate local surface plasmon resonance on the heterojunction surface, enhance light absorption, and thus increase the number of photons participating in the reaction. Moreover, by introducing other light-trapping materials, such as quantum dots, light absorption can be enhanced, and the generation efficiency of light-generated charge carriers can be improved. (3) Chalcogenides used as heterojunction photocatalysts often undergo photocorrosion and other problems that affect the stability of the prepared heterojunctions. It is necessary to enhance the stability of the heterojunction by further element doping and encapsulation of the heterojunction with protective layers or by selecting highly stable photocatalysts to combine with the heterojunction to improve its long-term use. (4) To efficiently enhance the photocatalytic activity of chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts and meet the expected performance requirements, further research and selection of suitable photocatalysts are needed to design chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts with a wide light absorption range, a large number of active sites, fast carrier separation, strong redox ability, and excellent stability. For example, by adjusting the morphology and size of heterojunction components, the fabrication of multidimensional nanostructured materials can increase the interfacial contact and specific surface area. In addition, porous materials can be used to increase the effective contact area and enhance the photocatalytic activity. Alternatively, the photocatalytic reaction efficiency can be improved by enhancing the reaction kinetics via surface functionalization of the photocatalyst to facilitate surface adsorption of the reactants. In addition, the efficiency of photocharge transfer can be improved, and the photocatalytic activity can be enhanced by introducing defects to inhibit the complexation of reduced carriers. (5) In photocatalyst application research, the targeted modification of photocatalysts according to different application scenarios can more effectively achieve the target application outcomes. For example, the surface state of a photocatalyst has been studied to improve water adsorption and thus increase hydrogen production activity by photocatalytic hydrolysis. Similarly, the regulation of the surface state of photocatalysts to increase CO2 adsorption efficiency and the selection of cocatalysts to regulate product selectivity should also be considered when studying photocatalytic CO2 reduction. (6) The concept of S-scheme heterojunctions has been widely used in the field of photocatalysis. However, it is also necessary to verify the carrier migration mechanism of the S-scheme heterojunction for the preparation of high-performance chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts. The use of intuitive in situ characterization techniques, such as in situ XPS, EPR, and DRIFTS, can effectively reveal the charge-transfer mechanism. The combination of in situ characterization and DFT can help further understand the photocatalytic mechanism, which is helpful for understanding the charge transfer and free energy change in the photocatalytic reaction and has important guiding significance for the design of new chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts. (7) The chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts have potential industrial applications. However, production costs and environmental safety must be considered for large-scale industrial applications. Using polluting cocatalysts, expensive raw materials, or preparation techniques to improve the photocatalytic performance is not a feasible option. Therefore, environmental safety and cost reduction are the key factors in the design of practical chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts. In summary, numerous studies have focused on developing and applying chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts; however, most of these efforts remain in their early stages. Further research is needed to maximize the practical use of S-scheme heterojunctions and enhance the photocatalytic efficiency of chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts. Kai Dai (Huaibei Normal University) was invited as a member of the Youth Editorial Board of Chinese Journal of Catalysis, Renewable and Sustainable Energy, Chinese Journal of Structural Chemistry and Acta Physico-Chimica Sinica. Prof. Kai Dai received his B.A. degree from Anhui University (China) in 2002, and Ph.D. degree from Shanghai University (China) in 2007. He worked in Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2007, and then in Huaibei Normal University in 2010. He is Distinguished Young Scholars Recipients of Natural Science Foundation of Anhui Province (2018) and serves as the head of Anhui Provincial Excellent research and innovation team in universities (2022) and Anhui Provincial Teaching Team (2019). He has also been invited by Xi'an Jiaotong Liverpool University to be a visiting Professor and PhD co-supervisor since 2022. His research interests mainly focus on semiconductor nanomaterials for solar energy conversion. He has published more than 150 peer-reviewed papers, including 11 hot paper of ESI and 24 highly cited papers of ESI. Hailiang Chu (School of Materials Science and Engineering, Guilin University of Electronic Technology) received his Ph.D. degree from Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2008. His research interests focus on the synthesis and application of high-performance electrode materials for secondary batteries and supercapacitors and high-capacity hydrogen storage materials, including alloys, metal borohydrides, metal-N-H materials, ammonia borane, and their derivatives. Lixian Sun (School of Materials Science and Engineering, Guilin University of Electronic Technology). He graduated from Hunan University with a Ph.D. degree in 1994. He is currently focusing on research in energy storage, especially hydrogen storage materials, biofuel cells, thermochemistry, and sensors.

coredata.dc:description: The unique photocatalytic mechanism of S-scheme heterojunction can be used to study new and efficient photocatalysts. By carefully selecting semiconductors for S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts, it is possible to reduce the rate of photogenerated carrier recombination and increase the conversion efficiency of light into energy. Chalcogenides are a group of compounds that include sulfides and selenides (e.g., CdS, ZnS, Bi2S3, MoS2, ZnSe, CdSe, and CuSe). Chalcogenides have attracted considerable attention as heterojunction photocatalysts owing to their narrow bandgap, wide light absorption range, and excellent photoreduction properties. This paper presents a thorough analysis of S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts based on chalcogenides. Following an introduction to the fundamental characteristics and benefits of S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts, various chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst synthesis techniques are summarized. These photocatalysts are used in numerous significant photocatalytic reactions, including the reduction of carbon dioxide, synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, conversion of organic matter, generation of hydrogen from water, nitrogen fixation, degradation of organic pollutants, and sterilization. In addition, cutting-edge characterization techniques, including in situ characterization techniques, are discussed to validate the steady and transient states of photocatalysts with an S-scheme heterojunction. Finally, the design and challenges of chalcogenide-based S-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts are explored and recommended in light of state-of-the-art research.
